( 2023 ) . Molecular Basis for Inhibition of Type ii-B Crispr-Cas by an Archaeal Viral Anti-Crispr Protein. 0.2139 / ssrn.4375100’. This has now been added to the manuscript as refernce 56 and subsequent references have been renumbered ccordingly. As a result, the following paragraph has been corrected: ‘Although AcrIIIB2 is only encoded by Sulfolobus virus IRV3 with its homolog undetected, our finding infers that ore unknown Acrs against Type III CRISPR–Cas systems are robably encoded by the mobile genetic elements and even heir hosts. Exploring these unknown Acrs will expand our nderstanding of the competition between CRISPR–Cas and nti-CRISPRs and could also raise the genetic tools to conrol CRISPR–Cas systems in diverse applications ( 56 ) , includng Type III CRISPR–Cas-based genome editing ( 57,58 ) and NA targeting ( 59 ) . In summary, our study provides a new nsight into the complexity of the prokaryote-virus arm race

sections.text: Nucleic Acids Research , 2023, 51 , 12537 https://doi.org/10.1093/nar/gkad1107 Advance access publication date: 11 November 2023

sections.heading: Correction
sections.text:
Correction to ‘An archaeal virus-encoded anti-CRISPR protein inhibits type III-B immunity by inhibiting Cas RNP complex turno v er’

D ow nloaded from https://academ ic.oup.com /nar/article/51/22/12537/7416387 b In the originally published version of this manuscript, refernce to the following pre-print paper was inadvertently omited: ‘Lin, Jinzhong & Alfastsen, Lauge & Bhoobalan, Yuvaraj Peng, Xu. ( 2023 ) . Molecular Basis for Inhibition of Type ii-B Crispr-Cas by an Archaeal Viral Anti-Crispr Protein. 0.2139 / ssrn.4375100’. This has now been added to the manuscript as refernce 56 and subsequent references have been renumbered ccordingly. As a result, the following paragraph has been corrected: ‘Although AcrIIIB2 is only encoded by Sulfolobus virus IRV3 with its homolog undetected, our finding infers that ore unknown Acrs against Type III CRISPR–Cas systems are robably encoded by the mobile genetic elements and even heir hosts. Exploring these unknown Acrs will expand our nderstanding of the competition between CRISPR–Cas and nti-CRISPRs and could also raise the genetic tools to conrol CRISPR–Cas systems in diverse applications ( 56 ) , includng Type III CRISPR–Cas-based genome editing ( 57,58 ) and NA targeting ( 59 ) . In summary, our study provides a new nsight into the complexity of the prokaryote-virus arm race
The Author ( s ) 2023. Published by Oxford University Press on behalf of Nuclei his is an Open Access article distributed under the terms of the Creative Comm hich permits unrestricted reuse, distribution, and reproduction in any medium,
and establishes a unique model for studying the structural and functional interplays between Acrs and Type III CRISPR–Cas systems.’
This paragraph now reads as follows: ‘It is worth noting that the inhibition of Cmr- α turnover by AcrIIIB2 and the detailed mechanism behind the inhibition were first reported by Lin et al. in a preprint article ( 56 ) , and our results are in line with their data. Although AcrIIIB2 is only encoded by Sulfolobus virus SIRV3 with its homolog undetected, our finding infers that more unknown Acrs against Type III CRISPR–Cas systems are probably encoded by the mobile genetic elements and even their hosts. Exploring these unknown Acrs will expand our understanding of the competition between CRISPR–Cas and anti-CRISPRs and could also raise the genetic tools to control CRISPR–Cas systems in diverse applications ( 57 ) , including Type III CRISPR–Cas-based genome editing ( 58,59 ) and RNA targeting ( 60 ) . In summary, our study provides a new insight into the complexity of the prokaryote-virus arm race and establishes a unique model for studying the structural and functional interplays between Acrs and Type III CRISPR–Cas systems.’
